revision.text:
{{short description|2003 single by Justin Timberlake}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}} {{Infobox song | name = Señorita | cover = Señorita.png | alt = A young man sitting, his back to the wall, facing to his right. He is wearing a T-shirt with a black jacket. The word "Señorita" is written in black bold font. In capitals, the name "Justin Timberlake" is written in white font. | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Justin Timberlake]] | album = [[Justified (album)|Justified]] | released = {{start date|2003|07|08}} | format = {{hlist|[[Maxi single]]|[[12-inch single|12"]]}} | recorded = 2002 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] | length = {{duration|m=4|s=54}} | label = [[Jive Records|Jive]] | writer = {{hlist|Justin Timberlake|[[Chad Hugo]]|[[Pharrell Williams]]}} | producer = [[The Neptunes]] | prev_title = [[Rock Your Body]] | prev_year = 2003 | next_title = [[I'm Lovin' It (song)|I'm Lovin' It]] | next_year = 2003 }}
"'''Señorita'''" is a song by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake]] for his debut studio album, ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'' (2002). It was released on July 8, 2003 by [[Jive Records]] as the fourth and final single from the album. He co-wrote the track with its producers [[Pharrell Williams]] and [[Chad Hugo]] of [[The Neptunes]].
According to Timberlake, the song was influenced by [[Stevie Wonder]]. Musically "Señorita" is an R&B, Pop, Jazz up-tempo ballad, featuring an electric piano strut, cowbell in beat of the song, and a rhythm section. The song has been described as a Spanish "number" with a "Latin flavored" cut beat.<ref name="spanish" /><ref name="sunday" /> In the track, Timberlake sings about a woman, whose attention he is trying to capture. "Señorita" received positive reviews from music critics, who commented on the track's general sound and lyrics.
Commercially, the song peaked within the top ten in Australia and New Zealand, the top twenty in Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the United Kingdom, and the top thirty in the Netherlands, Sweden, and the United States. Its music video was nominated for an [[MTV Video Music Award]] in the category for Best Male Video in 2004.
==Background and recording== "Señorita" was co-written by Justin Timberlake, and [[The Neptunes]]' [[Pharrell Williams]] and [[Chad Hugo]]. Before the release of Timberlake's solo album, ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'', Timberlake and the album's producers, Williams and Hugo, gave [[MTV News]] a preview of the record in August 2002. While in discussion of "Señorita", Hugo said that he expected the song to make the track listing of ''Justified''.<ref name="preview">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1457175/20020823/timberlake_justin.jhtml?headlines=true|title=Preview Of Justin Timberlake Album From Neptunes' Hugo|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|date=August 26, 2002|publisher=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009}}</ref> In another interview, Timberlake revealed that the song was influenced by singer-songwriter [[Stevie Wonder]].<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sarah|last=Rodman|title= Misic - 'N Solo — Justin Timberlake breaks out with `Justified'|date=November 1, 2002|work=[[Boston Herald]]|page=21}}</ref> Timberlake said that the song had "that groove that really fits into the summer".<ref name="just justin" /> While in development, Timberlake said he was "beatboxing the notes".<ref name="just justin" /> He wrote the song imagining a "dark-skinned, voluptuous lady whose attention he is trying to capture."<ref name="just justin">{{cite journal|first=Jessica|last=Ryen|title=Just Justin|date=June 8, 2003|work=[[Observer-Dispatch]]|page=01}}</ref>
==Composition== "Señorita" is a "Spanish number"<ref name="spanish">{{cite journal|first=Chelsea|last=Rogers|title=Justin's solo move justified|date=January 31, 2003|work=Centralian Advocate|page=018}}</ref> infused with an R&B, up-tempo ballad.<ref name="spanish" /><ref>{{cite journal|title=Evening Mail: Justin Time For Jamelia|date=May 13, 2003|work=[[Birmingham Mail]]|first=Alison|last=Dayani}}</ref> The song has been described as a fast "hot mid-tempo" and dance song.<ref name="preview" /><ref>{{cite journal|first=Bryan|last=Mochizuki|title=CD Review|date=November 10, 2002|work=[[The Sacramento Bee]]|page=E8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Tony|last=Hicks|title=Timberlake's Solo Career On Its Way With "Justified" - Album Lack Originality But Blends Jackson And Late '70s Funk Nicely|date=November 6, 2002|work=[[Contra Costa Times]]|page=d01}}</ref> The song is composed in the key of [[E-flat minor|E{{flat}} minor]] and is set in [[time signature]] of [[common time]] with a [[tempo]] of 96 [[beats per minute]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0045294|title=Justin Timberlake Digital Sheet Music: Senorita|accessdate=February 10, 2010|publisher=Musicnotes}}</ref> The music begins with an electric piano strut, that provides the main chordal accompaniment. A cowbell chimes, in beat of the song, in the background.<ref name="tyler">{{cite news|url=http://www.stylusmagazine.com/reviews/justin-timberlake/justified.htm |title=Justin Timberlake — Justified |last=Martin |first=Tyler |date=September 1, 2003 |work=[[Stylus Magazine|Stylus]] |accessdate=August 21, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510082227/http://stylusmagazine.com/reviews/justin-timberlake/justified.htm |archivedate=May 10, 2012 }}</ref> Timberlake sings in a "reasonable falsetto vamping".<ref>{{cite journal|first=Caroline|last=Sullivan|title=Sex bombs: Pop CD Releases: Justin Timberlake Justified|date=November 1, 2002|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> The song's musicscape also features hand claps,<ref>{{cite journal|first=Craig|last=Seymour|title='N Syncer's solo debut is satisfying surprise|date=November 5, 2002|work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|page=E1}}</ref> a rhythm section,<ref name="tyler" /> and "cruises on an unconventional reedy rhythm and crackling beat", according to Chuck Cavalaris of ''[[The Knoxville News-Sentinel]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Chuck|last=Cavalaris|title=Grohl's stature grows with 'One by One'|date=November 8, 2002|work=[[The Knoxville News-Sentinel]]|page=18}}</ref> The track is also considered a "blues inflected track",<ref>{{cite journal|title=Justin Goes Solo, Sort Of|date=July 24, 2003|work=[[The Cincinnati Post]]|page=T12}}</ref> and a dance jam.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sarah|last=Rodman|title=Justin shows he can Sync and swim|date=August 7, 2003|work=[[Boston Herald]]}}</ref> Kevin O'Hare of the ''[[The Republican (Springfield)|Sunday Republican]]'' said the song is "a Latin-flavored cut with a pronounced beat".<ref name="sunday" /> Lisa Rose of ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'' commented that the song has a "jazz-funk ... embellished with a ground-rumbling beat and horn section solos."<ref>{{cite journal|first=Lisa|last=Rose|title=Timberlake edges Aguilera as a pop makeover|date=August 23, 2003|work=[[The Star-Ledger]]|page=9}}</ref> ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'' said that the song has a "minimalist funk strut",<ref>{{cite journal|title=Disc Notes|date=November 15, 2002|work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]|page=19}}</ref> while a contributor of the ''[[New Straits Times]]'' said that the single is "a funk song with an organic feel – and quite close to Stevie Wonder's soulful style."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Nick and Justin go solo ..PX: (Nick Carter). ..PX: (Justin Timberlake)|date=December 8, 2002|work=[[New Straits Times]]}}</ref>
According to Teresa Gubbins of ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'', she described the theme of the song as Timberlake singing about a girl with brown eyes.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Teresa|last=Gubbins|title=Idols hedging their bets Timberlake and Carter branch out from groups|date=November 5, 2002|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|page=27A}}</ref> O'Hare noted that there are "some very amusing" improvisations as Timberlake guides the "guys and the ladies though their background vocal segment."<ref name="sunday">{{cite journal|first=Kevin|last=O'Hare|title=Singer's solo effort 'Justified'|date=November 10, 2002|work=[[The Republican (Springfield)|Sunday Republican]]|page=D01}}</ref> Stephen Thomas Erlewine of [[Allmusic]] also reported that Timberlake exhorts "the fellas and ladies" in "Señorita" to sing separately "in a cringe-worthy affectation".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=A0ek9iklsbb89 |title=Justified |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |date=November 5, 2002 |website=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=August 21, 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907161742/http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg |archivedate=September 7, 2009 }}</ref> He directs the men to sing, "It feels like something's heatin' up. Can I leave with you?" and the women to sing, "I don't know what I'm thinking bout / really leavin wit you."<ref name="impression">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1472336/20030605/aguilera_christina.jhtml?headlines=true|title=Christina Does Her Cher Impression, Justin Fights The Screams At Tour Kickoff|last=Fuoco|first=Christina|date=June 5, 2003|publisher=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=October 21, 2009}}</ref>
==Critical reception== Music critic [[David Browne (journalist)|David Browne]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', in review of the album, wrote: "In the latter category, he's more engaging—the stud on the loose, making promises of romance and more in slurpy cuts like 'Senorita' and '[[Rock Your Body]]'."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,384410,00.html|title=Justified (2002)|last=Browne|first=David|date=October 28, 2002|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009}}</ref> Denise Boyd of the [[BBC]] wrote: "The introduction [of] 'Senorita' immediately grabs your attention."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/vdmq|title=Justin Timberlake Justified Review|last=Boyd|first=Denise|date=November 20, 2002|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=August 20, 2009}}</ref> Tyler Martin of ''[[Stylus Magazine|Stylus]]'' said that the song's rhythm section was "brilliant, a simple, yet distinctive beat that could only come from the Neptunes. The song allows for much amusement in the last minute and a half with a sing-along that is more wonderful and surprising than most artists have offered us this year."<ref name="tyler"/> Jonathan Takiff of the ''[[Philadelphia Daily News]]'' wrote that the track and "Nothing Else", another song from the album, reshape "Stevie Wonder-style Latin pop".<ref>{{cite journal|first=Jonathan|last=Takiff|title=A Gray 'Midnight' - Singer reflects on death and pessimism|date=November 5, 2002|work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]|page=36}}</ref> Katie McDonald of [[Boston College]] wrote: "The album opens with the Latin and hip-hop influenced 'Senorita'. Although this reviewer was a little amused by Timberlake's use of the word 'Momma' in reference to a girl, this track is nothing to mock. Timberlake's voice complements the dynamic beat; and although the lyrics are in no way profound, at least he wrote them himself."<ref>{{cite news|first=Katie|last=McDonald|title=CD Review: Justin goes solo|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10062140_ITM|accessdate=August 21, 2009|publisher=[[Boston College]] | date=November 12, 2002}}</ref> Lisa Verrico of ''[[The Times]]'' wrote that the song could be [['NSYNC]] "with a salsa flavour".<ref>{{cite journal|first=Lisa|last=Verrico|title=The great pretenders — Pop|date=November 1, 2002|work=[[The Times]]|page=Times2 14}}</ref> Christian Dahlager of ''[[Iowa State Daily]]'' noted that Timberlake "cops classic [[Michael Jackson]]" throughout the album, and on the tracks "Señorita" and "Rock Your Body".<ref>{{cite journal|first=Christian|last=Dahlager|title=CD Review: Did Justin Timberlake just say that?|date=November 6, 2002|work=[[Iowa State Daily]]}}</ref> Howard Cohen of [[Knight Ridder]] said that in the album Timberlake "appropriates Jackson's trademark '[[Thriller (song)|Thriller]]'-era falsetto squeals and staccato vocal style on the tuneless first single '[[Like I Love You]]', 'Senorita' and a couple other cuts."<ref>{{cite news|first=Howard|last=Cohen|title=New from Justin Timberlake, Nick Carter, Tori Amos, TLC|date=November 12, 2002|publisher=[[Knight Ridder]]}}</ref>
The song received criticism as well. Jane Stevenson of [[Jam!]] wrote: "In the minus category is silly lead-off track 'Senorita', which suffers from being too cute and has an awful call-and-answer ending featuring 'the guys and the ladies.'"<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/T/Timberlake_Justin/AlbumReviews/2002/11/14/772032.html|title=Justified|last=Stevenson|first=Jane|date=November 14, 2002|magazine=[[Jam!]]|accessdate=August 21, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HlhD4yr4?url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/T/Timberlake_Justin/AlbumReviews/2002/11/14/772032.html|archivedate=June 30, 2013}}</ref> A music contributor from the ''Daily Free Press'' reported that The Neptunes appeared to have "recycled beats from their [[N.E.R.D]]. project" for ''Justified'' and that "Señorita" sounded like N.E.R.D.'s song, [[In Search Of... (N.E.R.D album)|"Run to the Sun]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyfreepress.com/2.5501/the-evolution-of-timberlake-from-sync-to-solo-1.938692|title=The evolution of Timberlake: from 'Sync to solo|accessdate=August 20, 2009|date=November 21, 2002|work=The Daily Free Press}}</ref>
==Chart performance== In North America, the single was officially solicited to radio in September 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.top40-charts.com/news.php?nid=5538|title=Single reviews released 8 September 2003|date=September 8, 2003|publisher=Top40 Charts|accessdate=October 21, 2009}}</ref> "Señorita" appeared on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and debuted at number 27.<ref name="all">{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p373055/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}}|title=Justin Timberlake > Charts & Awards|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=August 21, 2009}}</ref> It reached number 5 on the [[Mainstream Top 40]],<ref name="all" /> number 10 on the [[Top 40 Tracks]]<ref name="all" /> and number 29 on the [[Rhythmic (chart)|Rhythmic]].<ref name="all" />
The single performed averagely when it was released internationally. It debuted at number 13 in the [[United Kingdom]] for the week ending September 27, 2003. The song failed to achieve any higher position, and it fell for eight consecutive weeks until it left the charts completely.<ref name="uk"/> When it entered the [[Irish Singles Chart]], it did so at number 15. It spent seven weeks on the chart but failed to earn a higher position.<ref name="ire"/> In New Zealand, it charted at number 9 on September 14, 2003. During the following four weeks, it peaked at number 4 and remained there for two weeks. The song spent 15 weeks on the chart.<ref name="nz"/> In Australia, it peaked at number 6 and retired after spending eleven weeks on the chart.<ref name="aus"/> The single additionally charted in mainland European countries, peaking within the top 20 in several.
==Music video== The music video for "Señorita" was directed by [[Paul Hunter (director)|Paul Hunter]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-24171631_ITM|title=Justin Timberlake Announces NYC Show Post MTV Awards; Senorita Marks Fourth Consecutive Top 10 Single|last=Muckle|first=Sonia|author2=Benny Tarantini |date=August 22, 2003|publisher=[[PR Newswire]]|accessdate=August 21, 2009}}</ref> The video was filmed in July 2003 and shot in a club in Los Angeles. The video also features cameo appearances by both Pharrell Wiliams and Chad Hugo.<ref name="video" /> In mid-2003, Timberlake was asked about the concept of the video, but said that the video was still in development. He was asked whether he would be aiming his affection at a "lovely lady", to which Timberlake responded, "No. Why would you limit yourself to just one?"<ref name="video">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1474239/20030718/timberlake_justin.jhtml?headlines=true|title=Justin, Enjoying The Single Life, Gets Down With Horde Of 'Senoritas'|last=Patel|first=Joseph|author2=John Norris |date=July 18, 2003|publisher=[[MTV News]]|accessdate=August 21, 2009}}</ref> In the "Señorita" video, Timberlake performed with his live band.
The video begins, with the song playing, at an outside scenery of a bar. Inside, Timberlake is seen and goes directly to the bar. He looks at the stage area and immediately goes there. He takes the microphone and begins singing the song. Pharrell is shown playing the drums while Chad is at the keyboards throughout the video. Timberlake continues singing, but grabs the attention of a woman in a red dress. Elsewhere, Timberlake, not on stage, is shown dancing with a woman wearing a white blouse, while he sings the song. In another part of the video, Timberlake dances with a different woman. In the [[Bridge (music)|bridge]], he sings to the two women and dances with them, in separate shots. Following the bridge he is then seen performing on stage. In part of the song, Timberlake directs the crowd of men and women, telling the men to sing, "It feels like something's heatin' up. Can I leave with you?" and the women to sing, "I don't know what I'm thinking bout / really leavin wit you."<ref name="impression"/> Timberlake ends the song with "Gentlemen, good night / Ladies good morning".
Actor [[Owen Wilson]] and his then-girlfriend, Carolina Cerisola, appear in the video.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Splitsville: Owen Wilson has given dancer girlfriend Carolina Cerisola the big bounce|date=October 5, 2004|publisher=[[RedEye]]|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=34}}</ref> Lanford Beard of ''Middlebury College Student Weekly'', in review of the video, wrote that Timberlake's "Mexicali saloon setting" for the video "embraced a certain macho, trashy playa aesthetic" for him "so we'll take it on the chin that this is the image he's building for himself and – love it or hate it – we might as well get used to it."<ref name="lanford">{{cite news|url=http://media.www.middleburycampus.com/media/storage/paper446/news/2003/11/13/Features/Pop-Rocks-556804.shtml|title=Pop Rocks|last=Beard|first=Lanford|date=November 13, 2003|work=Middlebury College Student Weekly|page=1|accessdate=August 21, 2009|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20070613161341/http://media.www.middleburycampus.com/media/storage/paper446/news/2003/11/13/Features/Pop-Rocks-556804.shtml|archivedate=June 13, 2007}}</ref> In 2004, the video was nominated for an [[MTV Video Music Award]] in the category of Best Male Video.<ref>{{cite journal|title=MTV Awards Are Set|date=July 28, 2004|work=[[New York Post]]|page=080}}</ref><!--<ref>{{cite journal|first=Sean|last=Piccoli|title=MTV's Gala 'Reinvented' - Video Music Awards Will Embrace South Florida Style|date=July 28, 2004|work=[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|page=1A}}</ref>-->
==Live performances== [[File:Justin Timberlake - Señorita 2007.jpg|thumb|right|190px|alt=A stage with a big screen display showing a man with a beard. Sitting in a piano, a man with long curly hair wears a white shirt, with the sleeves roll back, and a black vest, plays the piano. To the man's left, a man can be seen standing playing an electric piano.|Justin Timberlake on a piano while singing "Señorita" during his 2007 [[FutureSex/LoveShow]] concert tour]] Timberlake performed the song live on the sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in October 2003, where he served as host and musical guest.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Justin Timberlake |episodelink= |series=Saturday Night Live |serieslink= |credits= |network=[[NBC]] |station= |airdate=October 11, 2003 |season=[[Saturday Night Live (season 29)|29]] |seriesno= |number=547 |minutes=90-92 }}</ref> At the [[46th Grammy Awards]] in 2004, he also performed the song live and was accompanied by [[Latin jazz]] trumpeter [[Arturo Sandoval]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/awards/grammys/2004-02-09-grammy-main_x.htm|title=High-five salute for Beyoncé|last=Barnes|first=Ken|date=February 9, 2004|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=August 23, 2009}}</ref> On August 25, 2013, he performed "Señorita" in a medley with other of his songs at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]].
"Señorita" was featured on [[Justin Timberlake: Live from London]] (2002), [[Justified and Stripped Tour]] (2003), [[FutureSex/LoveShow]] (2007), [[Legends of the Summer]] (2013) and [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour]] (2013/14).
==Track listing== '''European CD Single''' #"Señorita" (Album version) – 4:54 #"Señorita" (Instrumental) – 4:54 #"Señorita" (Eddie's Extended Club Mix) – 6:27 #"[[Rock Your Body]]" (Vasquez Club Anthem) – 9:15 #"Señorita" (Video) – 4:33
'''UK CD Single''' #"Señorita" (Radio Edit Short Intro) – 4:16 #"Señorita" (Eddie's Crossover Rhythm Mix) – 4:18 #"Señorita" (Eddie's Extended Dance Mix) – 6:27 #"Señorita" (Dr. Octavo 2-Step Mix) – 3:50
